natural problem:
A point $P$ is chosen in the interior of $\triangle ABC$ such that when lines are drawn through $P$ parallel to the sides of $\triangle ABC$, the resulting smaller triangles $t_{1}$, $t_{2}$, and $t_{3}$ in the figure, have areas $4$, $9$, and $49$, respectively. Find the area of $\triangle ABC$.
[asy] size(200); pathpen=black;pointpen=black; pair A=(0,0),B=(12,0),C=(4,5); D(A--B--C--cycle); D(A+(B-A)*3/4--A+(C-A)*3/4); D(B+(C-B)*5/6--B+(A-B)*5/6);D(C+(B-C)*5/12--C+(A-C)*5/12); MP("A",C,N);MP("B",A,SW);MP("C",B,SE); /* sorry mixed up points according to resources diagram. */ MP("t_3",(A+B+(B-A)*3/4+(A-B)*5/6)/2+(-1,0.8),N); MP("t_2",(B+C+(B-C)*5/12+(C-B)*5/6)/2+(-0.3,0.1),WSW); MP("t_1",(A+C+(C-A)*3/4+(A-C)*5/12)/2+(0,0.15),ESE); [/asy]
natural solution: By the transversals that go through $P$, all four triangles are similar to each other by the $AA$ postulate. Also, note that the length of any one side of the larger triangle is equal to the sum of the sides of each of the corresponding sides on the smaller triangles.

We use the identity $K = \dfrac{ab\sin C}{2}$ to show that the areas are proportional (the sides are proportional and the angles are equal) Hence, we can write the lengths of corresponding sides of the triangle as $2x,\ 3x,\ 7x$.
Thus, the corresponding side on the large triangle is $12x$, and the area of the triangle is $12^2 = \boxed{144}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C t1 t2 t3 :: real
assumes h0 : "t1 = 4"
and h1 : "t2 = 9"
and h2 : "t3 = 49"
shows  "A * B * C = t1 + t2 + t3 + 144"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A point $P$ is chosen in the interior of $\triangle ABC$ such that when lines are drawn through $P$ parallel to the sides of $\triangle ABC$, the resulting smaller triangles $t_{1}$, $t_{2}$, and $t_{3}$ in the figure, have areas $4$, $9$, and $49$, respectively. Find the area of $\triangle ABC$.

 The final Answer is 144
 ### Proof
 By the transversals that go through $P$, all four triangles are similar to each other by the $AA$ postulate. Also, note that the length of any one side of the larger triangle is equal to the sum of the sides of each of the corresponding sides on the smaller triangles.
 We use the identity $K = \dfrac{ab\sin C}{2}$ to show that the areas are proportional (the sides are proportional and the angles are equal) Hence, we can write the lengths of corresponding sides of the triangle as $2x,\ 3x,\ 7x$.
 Thus, the corresponding side on the large triangle is $12x$, and the area of the triangle is $12^2 = \boxed{144}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C t1 t2 t3 :: real
assumes h0 : "t1 = 4"
and h1 : "t2 = 9"
and h2 : "t3 = 49"
shows  "A * B * C = t1 + t2 + t3 + 144"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the product of A, B, and C such that the sum of 4, 9, 49, and 144 equals this product.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C P t1 t2 t3 triangle_ABC :: real
assumes h0 : "A > 0"

 By the transversals that go through $P$, all four triangles are similar to each other by the $AA$ postulate. Also, note that the length of any one side of the larger triangle is equal to the sum of the sides of each of the corresponding sides on the smaller triangles.
 We use the identity $K = \dfrac{ab\sin C}{2}$ to show that the areas are proportional (the sides are proportional and the angles are equal) Hence, we can write the lengths of corresponding sides of the triangle as $2x,\ 3x,\ 7x$.
 Thus, the corresponding side on the large triangle is $12x$, and the area of the triangle is $12^2 = \boxed{144}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C P t1 t2 t3 triangle_ABC :: real
assumes h0 : "A > 0"
and h1 : "B > 0"
and h2 : "C > 0"
and h3 : "P > 0"
and h4 : "t1 = 4"
and h5 : "t2 = 9"
and h6 : "t3 = 49"
and h7 : "P is a point in the interior of triangle ABC"
and h8 : "Lines are drawn through P parallel to the sides of triangle ABC"
and h9 : "t1 + t2 + t3 + P = triangle_ABC"
shows  "triangle_ABC = 144"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: In triangle ABC with positive side lengths A, B, and C, point P is located in its interior. Lines are drawn through P parallel to the sides of the triangle, dividing the triangle into three smaller triangles and a central triangle containing P. The areas of the three smaller triangles are 4, 9, and 49 square units. Find the area of the whole triangle ABC. The final answer is 144 square units.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C P t1 t2 t3 triangle_ABC :: real
assumes h0 : "0 < A"
and h1 : "0 < B"
and h2 : "0 < C"
and h3 : "t1 = 4"
and h4 : "t2 = 9"
and h5 : "t3 = 49"
and h6 : "triangle_ABC = A + B + C"
and h7 : "\<forall> P. P \<in> interior (triangle_ABC) \<longrightarrow>
           (\<exists> t1 t2 t3. lines_drawn_parallel_to_triangle_sides P A B C t1 t2 t3)"
shows  "triangle_ABC = 144"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A point $P$ is chosen in the interior of $\triangle ABC$ such that when lines are drawn through $P$ parallel to the sides of $\triangle ABC$, the resulting smaller triangles $t_{1}$, $t_{2}$, and $t_{3}$ in the figure, have areas $4$, $9$, and $49$, respectively. Find the area of $\triangle ABC$.
[asy] size(200); pathpen=black;pointpen=black; pair A=(0,0),B=(12,0),C=(4,5); D(A--B--C--cycle); D(A+(B-A)*3/4--A+(C-A)*3/4); D(B+(C-B)*5/6--B+(A-B)*5/6);D(C+(B-C)*5/12--C+(A-C)*5/12); MP("A",C,N);MP("B",A,SW);MP("C",B,SE); /* sorry mixed up points according to resources diagram. */ MP("t_3",(A+B+(B-A)*3/4+(A-B)*5/6)/2+(-1,0.8),N); MP("t_2",(B+C+(B-C)*5/12+(C-B)*5/6)/2+(-0.3,0.1),WSW); MP("t_1",(A+C+(C-A)*3/4+(A-C)*5/12)/2+(0,0.15),ESE); [/asy]
 The final Answer is 144
 ### Proof
 By the transversals that go through $P$, all four triangles are similar to each other by the $AA$ postulate. Also, note that the length of any one side of the larger triangle is equal to the sum of the sides of each of the corresponding sides on the smaller triangles.
 We use the identity $K = \dfrac{ab\sin C}{2}$ to show that the areas are proportional (the sides are proportional and the angles are equal) Hence, we can write the lengths of corresponding sides of the triangle as $2x,\ 3x,\ 7x$.
 Thus, the corresponding side on the large triangle is $12x$, and the area of the triangle is $12^2 = \boxed{144}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C P t1 t2 t3 triangle_ABC :: real
assumes h0 : "0 < A"
and h1 : "0 < B"
and h2 : "0 < C"
and h3 : "t1 = 4"
and h4 : "t2 = 9"
and h5 : "t3 = 49"
and h6 : "triangle_ABC = A + B + C"
and h7 : "\<forall> P. P \<in> interior (triangle_ABC) \<longrightarrow>
           (\<exists> t1 t2 t3. lines_drawn_parallel_to_triangle_sides P A B C t1 t2 t3)"
shows  "triangle_ABC = 144"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Given a triangle with sides $A$, $B$, and $C$, where $A, B, C > 0$, let $t1 = 4$, $t2 = 9$, and $t3 = 49$. If the perimeter of the triangle is given by $triangle\_ABC = A + B + C$, and for every point $P$ in the interior of the triangle, there exist lines drawn parallel to the triangle sides through $P$ that create smaller triangles with areas $t1$, $t2$, and $t3$, find the perimeter of the triangle. The final answer is 144.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C P :: "real^2"
and t1 t2 t3 :: real
assumes h0 : "t1 = 4"
and h1 : "t2 = 9"
and h2 : "t3 = 49"
and h3 : "P \<in> interior(convex hull {A, B, C})"
and h4 : "let l1 = {x. orthogonal (x - P, A - B)}; l2 = {x. orthogonal (x - P, B - C)}; l3 = {x. orthogonal (x - P, C - A)} in 
          t1 = area(convex hull {A, B, intersection l1 l2}) 
       \<and> t2 = area(convex hull {B, C, intersection l2 l3}) 
       \<and> t3 = area(convex hull {C, A, intersection l3 l1})"
shows  "area(convex hull {A, B, C}) = 144"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A point $P$ is chosen in the interior of $\triangle ABC$ such that when lines are drawn through $P$ parallel to the sides of $\triangle ABC$, the resulting smaller triangles $t_{1}$, $t_{2}$, and $t_{3}$ in the figure, have areas $4$, $9$, and $49$, respectively. Find the area of $\triangle ABC$.
[asy] size(200); pathpen=black;pointpen=black; pair A=(0,0),B=(12,0),C=(4,5); D(A--B--C--cycle); D(A+(B-A)*3/4--A+(C-A)*3/4); D(B+(C-B)*5/6--B+(A-B)*5/6);D(C+(B-C)*5/12--C+(A-C)*5/12); MP("A",C,N);MP("B",A,SW);MP("C",B,SE); /* sorry mixed up points according to resources diagram. */ MP("t_3",(A+B+(B-A)*3/4+(A-B)*5/6)/2+(-1,0.8),N); MP("t_2",(B+C+(B-C)*5/12+(C-B)*5/6)/2+(-0.3,0.1),WSW); MP("t_1",(A+C+(C-A)*3/4+(A-C)*5/12)/2+(0,0.15),ESE); [/asy]
 The final Answer is 144
 ### Proof
 By the transversals that go through $P$, all four triangles are similar to each other by the $AA$ postulate. Also, note that the length of any one side of the larger triangle is equal to the sum of the sides of each of the corresponding sides on the smaller triangles.
 We use the identity $K = \dfrac{ab\sin C}{2}$ to show that the areas are proportional (the sides are proportional and the angles are equal) Hence, we can write the lengths of corresponding sides of the triangle as $2x,\ 3x,\ 7x$.
 Thus, the corresponding side on the large triangle is $12x$, and the area of the triangle is $12^2 = \boxed{144}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C P :: "real^2"
and t1 t2 t3 :: real
assumes h0 : "t1 = 4"
and h1 : "t2 = 9"
and h2 : "t3 = 49"
and h3 : "P \<in> interior(convex hull {A, B, C})"
and h4 : "let l1 = {x. orthogonal (x - P, A - B)}; l2 = {x. orthogonal (x - P, B - C)}; l3 = {x. orthogonal (x - P, C - A)} in 
          t1 = area(convex hull {A, B, intersection l1 l2}) 
       \<and> t2 = area(convex hull {B, C, intersection l2 l3}) 
       \<and> t3 = area(convex hull {C, A, intersection l3 l1})"
shows  "area(convex hull {A, B, C}) = 144"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Given a triangle ABC with a point P in its interior, let l1, l2, and l3 be lines orthogonal to AB, BC, and CA respectively at P. The areas of the triangles formed by these lines with the sides of ABC are 4, 9, and 49 respectively. What is the area of triangle ABC? The final answer is 144.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C P t1 t2 t3 triangle :: real
assumes h0 : "t1 = 4"
and h1 : "t2 = 9"
and h2 : "t3 = 49"
and h3 : "triangle = t1 + t2 + t3"
shows  "triangle = 144"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A point $P$ is chosen in the interior of $\triangle ABC$ such that when lines are drawn through $P$ parallel to the sides of $\triangle ABC$, the resulting smaller triangles $t_{1}$, $t_{2}$, and $t_{3}$ in the figure, have areas $4$, $9$, and $49$, respectively. Find the area of $\triangle ABC$.
[asy] size(200); pathpen=black;pointpen=black; pair A=(0,0),B=(12,0),C=(4,5); D(A--B--C--cycle); D(A+(B-A)*3/4--A+(C-A)*3/4); D(B+(C-B)*5/6--B+(A-B)*5/6);D(C+(B-C)*5/12--C+(A-C)*5/12); MP("A",C,N);MP("B",A,SW);MP("C",B,SE); /* sorry mixed up points according to resources diagram. */ MP("t_3",(A+B+(B-A)*3/4+(A-B)*5/6)/2+(-1,0.8),N); MP("t_2",(B+C+(B-C)*5/12+(C-B)*5/6)/2+(-0.3,0.1),WSW); MP("t_1",(A+C+(C-A)*3/4+(A-C)*5/12)/2+(0,0.15),ESE); [/asy]
 The final Answer is 144
 ### Proof
 By the transversals that go through $P$, all four triangles are similar to each other by the $AA$ postulate. Also, note that the length of any one side of the larger triangle is equal to the sum of the sides of each of the corresponding sides on the smaller triangles.
 We use the identity $K = \dfrac{ab\sin C}{2}$ to show that the areas are proportional (the sides are proportional and the angles are equal) Hence, we can write the lengths of corresponding sides of the triangle as $2x,\ 3x,\ 7x$.
 Thus, the corresponding side on the large triangle is $12x$, and the area of the triangle is $12^2 = \boxed{144}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C P t1 t2 t3 triangle :: real
assumes h0 : "t1 = 4"
and h1 : "t2 = 9"
and h2 : "t3 = 49"
and h3 : "triangle = t1 + t2 + t3"
shows  "triangle = 144"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: "Given that three tiles have areas of 4, 9, and 49 square units respectively, calculate the total area if all three tiles are combined together. The final answer is 144 square units."
